chapter.title: Introduction
chapter.para: MacPorts is a system for building, installing, and managing free and open source software. MacPorts "ports" are definitions of applications, their characteristics, and any files or special instructions required to install them in files named Portfiles, so MacPorts may automatically fetch, patch, compile, and install ported applications.

MacPorts may also be used to pre-compile ported applications into binaries that may be installed on remote computers. Binaries of ported applications may be installed very quickly since the steps required to install ports from source code have all been performed in advance. MacPorts provides several major advantages over installing free and open source software manually.

listitem.para: MacPorts automatically installs a given port's required support applications or libraries, known as "dependencies".
MacPorts confines ported software to a private "sandbox" that keeps it from intermingling with your operating system and its vendor-supplied libraries and prevents them from becoming corrupted.
MacPorts provides automatic uninstalls and upgrades of ported software.

chapter.para: MacPorts is developed on Mac OS X, though it is designed to be portable so it can work on other Unix-like systems, especially those descended from the Berkeley Software Distribution (BSD).

section.title: Document Conventions
